title: Tucker Carlson says 'there is no good way to spin this' and criticizes Trump content of Ukraine call
text:
Fox News host Tucker Carlson said in an op-ed that Trump shouldn't have asked the leader of Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden and that 'there's no way to spin this as a good idea.'

'Donald Trump should not have been on the phone with a foreign head of state encouraging another country to investigate his political opponent, Joe Biden,' Carlson wrote in the opening of the op-ed he co-wrote with Neil Patel, which was posted on The Daily Caller, their right-wing news website late Wednesday night.

'Some Republicans are trying, but there’s no way to spin this as a good idea,' Carlson and Patel added.

Fox News host Tucker Carlson wrote an op-ed criticizing President Trump for asking the President of the Ukraine to investigate political opponent Joe Biden

The op-ed, which Carlson (left) co-wrote with Neil Patel (right) appeared on their Daily Caller website Wednesday night, just hours before Mitt Romney criticized Trump

The op-ed went on to say: 'Like a lot of things Trump does, it was pretty over-the-top. Our leaders’ official actions should not be about politics. Those two things need to remain separate. Once those in control of our government use it to advance their political goals, we become just another of the world’s many corrupt countries.

'America is better than that,' Carlson and Patel wrote.

Despite the critique of Trump's actions, Carlson said that 'it's hard to argue' that Trump's call with Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky is an impeachable offense.

Despite saying that Trump (left) shouldn't have asked Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky (right) to investigate Joe Biden, Carlson and Patel said it was not an impeachable offense

'The president did not, as was first reported, offer a quid pro quo to the Ukrainians. He did not condition any U.S. support on a Biden investigation. The Justice Department has already looked at the totality of the call and determined that Trump did not break the law,' Carlson and Patel wrote.

CNN analyst Abby Phillip said that the op-ed was 'a pretty transparent effort to provide a roadmap for Republicans looking for a way to publicly condemn Trump's actions but still oppose impeachment.'

Carlson and Patel's op-ed was posted just hours before prominent Republican Mitt Romney criticized the president on Twitter, saying that asking the Ukraine and China to investigate Joe Biden was 'wrong and appalling.'
description: 'Donald Trump should not have been on the phone with a foreign head of state encouraging another country to investigate his political opponent, Joe Biden,' Tucker Carlson wrote in an op-ed.
